intro: Allium porrum, commonly known as leek, is a member of the Amaryllidaceae family and is closely related to onions and garlic. It is a biennial plant that typically grows to a height of 30–90 cm, with long, cylindrical, hollow leaves that form a rosette. The edible part of the plant is the stalk, which is harvested before flowering, usually in the second growing season. Leeks prefer cool climates and well-drained soil, and they are often cultivated in temperate regions. The plant produces small, white or pale purple flowers in umbels, which eventually develop into dry, three-lobed capsules containing numerous seeds.
